awd_titl_txt: High-Performance Panoptic Mass Spectrometry for Electrocatalytic Reaction Screening
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-B and Chemical Measurement and Imaging Programs, Professor Abraham Badu-Tawiah of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Ohio State University is developing a new electrocatalytic screening platform for the selective reactions (oxidation) of carbon carbon double bonds. The project seeks to identify electrocatalytic conditions that enable selective synthesis of high-value fine chemicals.  Education and outreach activities are designed to directly impact students in the early stages (K-12) of their educational experience. The project is well-positioned to introduce students - including groups underrepresented in the STEM fields - to interdisciplinary science. 

The majority of heterogeneous electrocatalysts are oxides or metals dispersed onto oxide supports. Traditionally, oxide synthesis and subsequent reactivity screening occur separately in two independent experiments. This project targets an all-in-one panoptic system that combines in-situ oxide synthesis and catalytic reaction screening into a single experimental step.  The research involves the development of a multimodal, contained, nano-electrospray system for  the in-situ preparation of the eletrocatalyst and subsequent modification of the reaction environment in real-time.  Anodic reaction screening is investigated using the electrooxidation of alkenes by non-inert metal electrodes to produce several important reactive chemical intermediates. Cathodic reaction screening is showcased using the selective reduction of carbon carbon double bonds in the presence of carbon oxygen double bonds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overall, by the end of Year 3, this project had explored all phases of medium for which chemical reaction is possible, including solution-phase, droplet-phase, plasma-droplet phase, and gas-phase. We have shown that chemical reactions can be combined with the analysis of various analytes during online mass spectrometry, ranging from large biomolecular proteins, peptides, small organic molecules, and lipids. We have created a multitude analytical devices that made possible the selected chemical reactions. A prototype of the contained nESI/APCI source is under development. The capabilities of the contained-ESI source have been greatly improved allowing this reactive source to cover a range of different chemical reactions. Lastly, we have invented the new concept of panoptic mass spectrometry that is related to the creation of a four-quadrant mass spectrometry approach. This approach allows anodic and cathodic electrocatalytic experiments to be performed independently of the mode of operation of the mass spectrometers. This enables detailed mechanistic investigations that are not possible on the traditional electrochemical mass spectrometry experiments where the electrochemical cell is intimately linked to the mass analyzer.

Within the past three years, we published 12 papers, including Kulyk, D.S.; Swiner, D.J.; Sahraeian, T.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Anal. Chem., 2019, 91(18), 11562-11568; Miller, C.; Burris, B.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom., 2020, 31, 1499?1508; Chintalapudi, K.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Chem. Sci., 2020, 11, 9891; Kulyk, D.S.; Amoah, E.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Anal. Chem., 2020, 92, 15025?15033; Lee, S.; Kulyk, D.S.; Marano, N.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Anal. Chem. 2021, 93, 4, 2440; Frey, B.S.; Damon, D.; Allen, D.M.; Baker, J.; Asamoah, S.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Analyst, 2021, 146, 6780 ? 6787; Heiss, D.R.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Anal. Chem., 2021, 93, 50, 16779?16786; Kulyk, D.S.; Sahraeian, T.; Lee, S.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Analytical Chemistry, 2021, 93, 13632?13640; Burris, B.J.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Anal. Chem., 2021, 93, 13001?13007; Swiner, D.J.; Kulyk, D.S.; Osae, H.; Durisek, G.R.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Anal. Chem. 2022, 94, 5, 2358?2365; Frey, B.S.; Heiss, D.R.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Anal. Chem. 2022, 94, 10, 4417?4425; Frey, B.S.; Damon, D.E.; Badu-Tawiah, A.K. Anal. Chem., 2022 DOI:10.1021/acs.analchem.2c00711

In 2021, the PI was able to graduate nine (9) PhD students, many of whom were directly or indirectly involved in this project, including Dr. Sierra Jackson, Dr. Devin Swiner, Dr. Suji Lee, Dr. Benji Frey, Dr. Kavyasree Chintalapudi, Dr. Savithra Jayaraj, Dr. Ben Burris, Dr. Derik Heiss, and Dr. Mickey Rogers. The Badu-Tawiah research group offers student training at all levels, including postdoctoral, graduate, undergraduate, high school, and middle school educational experiences. This unique opportunity is possible because of the simplicity of our experiments involving inexpensive home-made devices, which mitigates the risk of working with novice.

After returning from COVID lockdown in 2021, 14 undergraduate researchers (Nicholas Marano, Jill Baker, Danyelle M. Allen, Samuel Asamoah, George R. Durisek III, Bridgette Agbodza, Ashley S. Thomas, Trae Wilson, Michelle Maina, Nava Ramazanali, Hannah Osae, Maia Bates, Leah Walsh,  and Anna Nordmann) and two (2) researchers from a local high school (Solomon Lisath and Anish Gupta, both from St. Charles Preparatory School, Columbus, Ohio) participated in research activities directly related to the specific objectives of the project. Ten (10) of the undergraduate advisees (71%) were female and seven (50%; Samuel Asamoah, Bridgette Agbodza, Ashley S. Thomas, Trae Wilson, Michelle Maina, Hannah Osae, and Maia Bates) were African American. We are able to recruit underrepresented minorities because of our ?Science-in-Reverse? educational program in which the PI uses his own example and progress as a mirror image for students. We pay special attention to the needs of minorities; we employ a hierarchical engagement approach where students at a higher educational level engage the next lower level. Most of the undergraduate researchers worked in regular school year but about 40% of them participated in intensive 10-week research internship programs organized in the PI?s laboratory during the summer months and were supported by LSAMP (Louis Stokes Alliance Minority Partnership), a local OSU MUSE (Mentoring Undergraduate Scholars for Excellence) program, and project funds from this grant. By participating in interdisciplinary research at the interface of organic chemistry, analytical chemistry, and biomedicine, the students gain critical thinking, problem solving, and effective communication skills as well as hands-on experience with cutting edge research techniques. Students who participate in the summer research program worked independently but also within a research team having a common goal, which provided considerable opportunities for informal discussion of the results between the students and exposure to scientific research in a highly collaborative environment.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2022
Modified by: Abraham K Badu-Tawiah
